pr_title: Fix non-deterministic issue for annotations in the generated data template code by using right schema location for typeref class template

timeline.message: Fix the non-deterministic issue by sorting source schema files everytime

timeline.bodyText: can you test using PDL? not to say pdsc is not good for this kind of testing, But since we are migrating to PDL. Need to make sure PDL is actually working. Also if we use PDL now, we don't need to worry about later they are migrated in this MP
timeline.author: junchuanwang

timeline.bodyText: as we discussed offline, Please confirm if the inline typeref's dataSchemaLocation is also using enclosingSchema's location.
timeline.author: junchuanwang

replies.bodyText: Junchuan, I confirmed this in my new added test case
replies.author: BrianPin

timeline.message: Add inline record test and PDL typed file test

timeline.bodyText:
I think the only 2 cases you need are
{"BRecord.pdl", "InlineRecord.java"},
{"InlineRecord.java", "BRecord.pdl"},"
Unless you want to test duplicates  like you have here.
timeline.author: Astro03
Astro03

replies.bodyText: this is removed (by addressing Karthik's comment)
replies.author: BrianPin

timeline.bodyText: nit: testDataTemplateGenerationDeterminism  (the Deterministic in the sentence doesn't make sense)
timeline.author: Astro03
Astro03

replies.bodyText: Yes, thanks, addressed into a single data provider "test_schema_permutation_deterministic"
replies.author: BrianPin

replies.bodyText:
I see that you changed to a single data provider but you still have only 1 input arrray into your test, then within your test, you split it up by dividing by 2.
You should have two separate arrays, one for each variable. It makes it a lot easier to understand the logic within your code/test.
replies.author: Astro03

timeline.bodyText: A better way to test this (and avoid having to update java files everytime code generation logic changes) is to take two arrays of Pegasus schemas as input (in different order) and then generate the source files and compare they are same.
timeline.author: karthikbalasub

replies.bodyText:
That was my first attempt, sometime today in my chat with Astro, I changed to current way.
I think ...... I can do the original way
replies.author: BrianPin

replies.bodyText:
I think you can just generate MD5 for all the generated files together by xor-ing individual MD5s and compare. It would be simpler than current logic.
See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47253864/order-independent-hash-in-java
replies.author: karthikbalasub

replies.bodyText: I was talking about this comment. What did i suggest?
replies.author: Astro03

timeline.bodyText:
I suggest you return two arrays of strings as input.
Eg
{{"IsoDuration.pdsc", "PremiumService.pdsc"}, {"PremiumService.pdsc", "IsoDuration.pdsc"}}

And add a comment explaining why order is important for this test.
timeline.author: karthikbalasub

replies.bodyText: Both of the two points are addressed, I added a comment on the DataProvider, Please let me know if the comment is clear
replies.author: BrianPin

timeline.bodyText: Is this guaranteed to return the files sorted alphabetically?
timeline.author: karthikbalasub

replies.bodyText: the returning files are not needed to be sorted, (if it sorts that is fine), the requirement is that for two consecutive calls of _tempDir.listFiles , the  returning files order shall be the same.
replies.author: BrianPin

replies.bodyText:
I don't see that consecutive calls would return the same order: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/io/File.html#listFiles()
I suggest sorting the generateFiles array to be sure this cannot cause flakiness.
replies.author: karthikbalasub

timeline.bodyText: This change here is happening is only because the test wasn't need to mock the schema location before, now it has to, so I have to patch this test, it is not because of any additional logic change
timeline.author: BrianPin

timeline.bodyText:
I guess I made a mistake in my suggestion, what I wanted is for this method to take 2 args:
(String[] inputSchemasOrder1, String[] inputSchemasOrder2)
timeline.author: karthikbalasub
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -205,4 +206,64 @@ private void testRunGenerator(String pegasusFilename, Map<String, String> expect
             file -> file.getName().replace(".java", ""),
             Function.identity()));
   }
+
+  /**
+   *
+   * @return an array of test cases where each case has two array of test schema file names. Those file names are
+   *   in the different permutations of same group of test schema files
+   */
+  @DataProvider(name = "test_schema_permutation_determinisim")
+  private Object[][] createPermutedDataTemplateCases()
+  {
+    return new Object[][]
+        {
+            {new String[]{"IsoDuration.pdsc", "PremiumService.pdsc"}, new String[]{"PremiumService.pdsc", "IsoDuration.pdsc"}},
+            {new String[]{"AField.pdl", "ARecord.pdl"}, new String[]{"ARecord.pdl", "AField.pdl"}},
+            {new String[]{"BRecord.pdl", "BField.pdl"}, new String[]{"BField.pdl", "BRecord.pdl"}},
+        };
+  }
+
+  @Test(dataProvider = "test_schema_permutation_determinisim")
+  public void testDataTemplateGenerationDeterminism(String[][] testArgs)

replies.bodyText: I agree, is this not how this test framework organizes the inputs for DataProviders?
replies.author: Astro03

Address all comments and made sure if the fix is not in place the test case will fail
Make naming of test data properly
